headline.main: Political Sway of the Military Is Subtly Spreading in China

docs.snippet: LEAD: While China's political leaders have removed themselves from sight to engage in a bitter struggle for power, there are signs that the military may be accumulating a larger role in the Chinese political process.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: While China's political leaders have removed themselves from sight to engage in a bitter struggle for power, there are signs that the military may be accumulating a larger role in the Chinese political process.

headline.main: A Portrait of a Young Man as a Beijing Student Leader

docs.snippet: LEAD: Four months ago a scrawny, scraggly-haired student gave speeches about human rights that baffled his classmates, who wondered how anyone could harbor such a passion for what was then a remote concept like democracy.

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Four months ago a scrawny, scraggly-haired student gave speeches about human rights that baffled his classmates, who wondered how anyone could harbor such a passion for what was then a remote concept like democracy.

headline.main: BEIJING RESIDENTS BLOCK ARMY MOVE NEAR CITY CENTER

docs.snippet: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Beijing students and workers surged onto the streets early this morning to turn back more than 2,000 troops who were marching toward Tiananmen Square.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Beijing students and workers surged onto the streets early this morning to turn back more than 2,000 troops who were marching toward Tiananmen Square.

headline.main: In the Streets, Anguish, Fury and Tears

docs.snippet: LEAD: As the crackle of automatic weapons filled the air today on the Avenue of Eternal Peace, tens of thousands of Beijing residents, even elderly men and women, rushed out to see what they could do to turn back the troops.

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As the crackle of automatic weapons filled the air today on the Avenue of Eternal Peace, tens of thousands of Beijing residents, even elderly men and women, rushed out to see what they could do to turn back the troops.

headline.main: The Beijing Spring: From Heady Defiance to Repression

docs.snippet: LEAD: Demonstrations by students and workers demanding greater democracy and an end to Government corruption went on for more than six weeks in Beijing's central Tiananmen Square before the authorities resorted to armed force to suppress them. Here a
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Demonstrations by students and workers demanding greater democracy and an end to Government corruption went on for more than six weeks in Beijing's central Tiananmen Square before the authorities resorted to armed force to suppress them. Here are the high points of the sustained protest, which has come to be regarded as a turning point for

headline.main: TROOPS ATTACK AND CRUSH BEIJING PROTEST; THOUSANDS FIGHT BACK, SCORES ARE KILLED

docs.snippet: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Chinese troops retook the center of the capital early this morning from pro-democracy protesters, killing scores of students and workers and wounding hundreds more as they fired submachine guns at crowds of people who tried

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Chinese troops retook the center of the capital early this morning from pro-democracy protesters, killing scores of students and workers and wounding hundreds more as they fired submachine guns at crowds of people who tried to resist.

headline.main: Crackdown in Beijing; Administration Ponders Steps on China

docs.snippet: LEAD: In the face of widespread Congressional outrage over the shooting down of protesters in Beijing, the Bush Administration is considering several steps to demonstrate criticism of the Chinese Government's use of force to end the protests, Adminis

byline.original: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In the face of widespread Congressional outrage over the shooting down of protesters in Beijing, the Bush Administration is considering several steps to demonstrate criticism of the Chinese Government's use of force to end the protests, Administration officials said today.

headline.main: ARMY TIGHTENS CONTROL OF CITY BUT ANGRY RESISTANCE GOES ON

docs.snippet: LEAD: Army units tightened their hold on the center of the Chinese capital on Sunday, moving in large convoys on some of the main thoroughfares and firing indiscriminately at crowds as outraged citizens continued to attack and burn army vehicles.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Army units tightened their hold on the center of the Chinese capital on Sunday, moving in large convoys on some of the main thoroughfares and firing indiscriminately at crowds as outraged citizens continued to attack and burn army vehicles.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.snippet: LEAD: Western nations and Chinese around the world condemned the military crackdown and bloodshed in Beijing yesterday with anguished protests, pleas for restraint and calls for economic and political sanctions against China.
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Western nations and Chinese around the world condemned the military crackdown and bloodshed in Beijing yesterday with anguished protests, pleas for restraint and calls for economic and political sanctions against China.
